awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Geometric Constraint based Concept Keyword Embedding for Domain-neutral Knowledge Graph Construction
awd_abstract_narration:
Many knowledge-driven applications, including question answering systems and AI based intelligent personal assistants depend critically on the availability of high quality knowledge graphs. However, existing knowledge graphs suffer from many limitations, including lack of completeness, and excessive need for human intervention. The objective of this proposal is to overcome these limitations by learning meaningful representation vectors for the entities and the relationships by combining sentential context of entities from text documents with the relational context of entities from existing knowledge bases.  Another objective is to develop methodologies for automatic extraction of entity-pairs and their relationships from natural language text.

The main intellectual merit of the proposed methodologies is the design of representation learning methodologies which can impose geometric constraints on the embedding vectors for capturing the underlying semantics; in other words, using the proposed method, the disposition of the learned vectors would capture various semantic relationships among the entities, including hierarchical, compositional, and sequential, which would yield high quality representation vectors for the entities, leading to high-quality knowledge- graphs. Validation of the proposed methods will be performed by building a living knowledge graph of all of computer science. In terms of broader impact, the proposed methods would benefit any information-heavy disciplines, for which, the construct and temporal evolution of a knowledge graph are critical. Also, there is a direct benefit to computer science as a discipline, since organizing and summarizing all the known and emerging concepts in computer science within a living and encyclopedic knowledge graph will enable better organization of new knowledge, and better search of related works from the existing literature.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this research PI has developed various machine learning models and algorithms for extracting entities from a sentence which exhibits various semantic relationships. Extracted entities can then be used for building a knowledge graph, where the extracted entities are nodes of the graph, and they are connected by an appropriately labeled relational edge. For instance, in the sentence, “diabetes is caused by the absence of insulin secretion, and vitamin D deficiency”, potentially extracted entities are: “diabetes”, “absence of insulin secretion”, and “vitamin D deficiency”. From these entities, two causality relations can be built: (diabetes, absence of insulin secretion) and (diabetes, vitamin D deficiency).  Given a large collection of medical research articles, algorithms proposed under this grant can be used for extracting such entities and identifying their relationship automatically to build a knowledge graph. The novelty of the proposed methods is many-fold: (1) The proposed algorithms can automatically identify syntactic patterns from a sentence which provides linguistic cues for any kind of semantic relationship. (2) The proposed algorithms can extract entities more accurately than the previous methods, specifically when the entity phrases span over many words. (3) For capturing is-a relationship, binary bits can be used for faithfully capturing hierarchical (is-a) relation between entities. Outcome of the research are 4 publications, and 3 software. Besides, using these algorithms a knowledge graph for computer science is also built (https://csknowledgegraph.org).
